Hi J.B.,
   Because I want to test what happens if I pass in a null into my=
 
method.  My method does certain business logic and I want to test 
that i=
t handles null properly.  So, in reality if the method's not 
private, I wo=
uld be able to call this:

String abc =3D "hello";
myMethod(null,abc);

so =
I want to see whether of myMethod throws the correct exception.

When using=
 PrivilegedAccessor.invokeMethod, then, I need to pass the 
two parameters =
of null and abc as an Object array for its third 
argument.  Does that make=
 sense?

Thanks,
Kris.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <=
jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
>
> krispyjala wrote:
> > Hello,
> >    I'm running i=
nto this problem where the PrivilegedAccessor 
cannot
> > find the method w=
hen using invokeMethod() if the Object array
> > contains a null value.
> >=
 
> > Ex:
> > 
> > PrivilegedAccessor.invokeMethod(Class.class,"myMethod",n=
ew Object
[]
> > {null,arg1});
> > 
> > I think the problem lies in the fac=
t that underneath, 
invokeMethod's
> > calling getMethod which calls anothe=
r getMethod, which ultimately
> > calls java.lang.getDeclaredMethod() which=
 only accepts an array of
> > classes.  Since null is not a class, it throw=
s an exception and 
thus
> > the private method is declared not found.  Am =
I right?  Or am I
> > missing something?
> > 
> > When I replaced the null =
with a valid object, it was able to find 
the
> > private method fine.  Is =
this a bug, or is this something that I
> > shouldn't be doing (setting nul=
l as an element in the Object 
array?).
> 
> In general, arrays can hold nu=
ll values; but in this particular 
case, 
> what is the null meant to signi=
fy? Why are you trying to pass null?
